title: Jane Horrocks webchat â as it happened | Stage | The Guardian
summary: 'the current trend of singing is just a bit too perfect for me '
'mike leigh allows you to be as creative as you possibly can . and i 'm feeling that liberated again at the moment '
post your questions for jane horrocks .

documents.title: that 's all for today !
text: thanks to everyone who submitted questions and to jane for her answers !
until next time .
cheers !
guardian contributor janehorrocks 02 march 2016 2:10pm thanks for your interesting and idiotic questions .
it 's helped pass my lunchtime very nicely .
if you kiss me kiss me is at the young vic from 10 march - 16 april .
i 'm at carcassonne airport now , where are you ?
sheepless asks : hi jane , huuuge fan here , looking forward to the new show !
i wanted to ask : in little voice , what was your reaction to michael caine 's amazing singing scene ?
guardian contributor janehorrocks 02 march 2016 2:00pm i was worried it might overshadow mine !
guardian contributor janehorrocks 02 march 2016 2:08pm in little voice , it was a nod to those singers who were my heroes .
but my other heroes were of this post-punk period , and with if you kiss me kiss me , i wanted to pay homage to them in a similar sort of way .
it was a very poignant part of my life when i was 17 , growing up with that music , and i feel particularly bands like joy division , and ian curtis 's voice , had a huge impact on my growing up .
i was into southern bands as well ; i just wanted this show to be much more specific .
when i was originally thinking about the idea , i was going to do the singers of little voice singing songs sung by dead singers .
including marilyn monroe singing an ian curtis song - isolation , which has echoes of marilyn still in it .
or billie holiday singing an amy winehouse song .
they all had to be dead .
but then i thought it was a little too macabre .
hilleauxthere asks : never mind the horrocks was one of the funniest and most memorable sketch shows i 've ever seen .
watch with nanny , philippa i could go on .
it was brilliant ( but i think you only made a pilot ?
alas . ) .
any chance you might try something like that again ?

guardian contributor janehorrocks 02 march 2016 1:59pm when i did that pilot , there had n't been many of that type of show previously , and since then there 's been numerous ones - it no longer seems a novel thing to do .

the good thing about doing something like if you kiss me kiss me is there 's no benchmark for it - you do sometimes feel a little at sea , but when there 's no comparison to be made , you have to trust your own instincts .
roghitch asks : going back in history of film .
what role would you have liked in films including musicals ?
guardian contributor janehorrocks 02 march 2016 1:57pm coal miner 's daughter , the biopic of loretta lynn .
not the tommy lee jones role , although he was very sexy .
i like sissy spacek , she 's one of my favourite actors , and i love the fact that she bowed out early - she did a run of amazing cult films , and has n't saturated the market with herself .
thepeoplespoet asks : which power ranger did you model your outfit on ?
guardian contributor janehorrocks 02 march 2016 1:55pm i am ignorant of the power rangers .
birgittenyborg2016 asks : i do n't want to ask you anything , jane .
just to tell you , as a 70 year-old , that it is possible to fall in love with a lass of 52 with a rawtenstall accent you could cut with a bread-knife .
you 've given this gent so much pleasure , jane .
thank you and never lose the rawtenstall voice .
guardian contributor janehorrocks 02 march 2016 1:54pm often london taxi drivers are quite bemused that i 've still got my accent and i 've lived in london so long .
i usually respond by saying : why would i want to speak like you ?

documents.title: 'the current trend of singing is just a bit too perfect for me '
text: jamesarc asks : hi jane !
in little voice you perform a range of judy garland classics in an eerie reproduction of her famous vibrato .
had you sung in her voice before ?
was this a party trick ?
or did you only approach these songs in this way for the film ?
( ps : sign my cd ! )
guardian contributor janehorrocks 02 march 2016 1:53pm jim cartwright who wrote little voice introduced me to judy garland , via the famous carnegie hall album in my mid-20s .
that vibrato absolutely taps me into her voice .
i always preferred her singing when she was older , because i responded to the emotional rawness of her voice and its imperfections .
i think the current trend of singing is just a bit too perfect for me .
murman asks : i wrote an album +49/electro murdo , sadly i did n't get signed but it'a on soundcloud !
are you going to cover are friends electric ?
by tubeway army , aka gary numan ?
guardian contributor janehorrocks 02 march 2016 1:50pm sadly i 'm not covering it .
i 'm a huge fan of gary 's and have met him , but he 's not northern .
he is male though .

documents.title: 'it 's quite nice playing thick '
text: paul sharman asks : have you ever wished that you were as daft as bubbles and float through life without a care in the world ?
she always seemed to be happy .
guardian contributor janehorrocks 02 march 2016 1:49pm it 's quite nice playing thick .

palfreyman asks : for me , the two performances that define how i think of you ( your versatility and sheer onscreen charm ) are from your roles in life is sweet and , of course , as bubble in abfab .
this is a total apples compared with oranges question , of course , but still 1 .
which did you enjoy working in more ?
which ( of the two ) do you think of as your better performance ?
many thanks for all these years of joy .
guardian contributor janehorrocks 02 march 2016 1:48pm as a result of life is sweet , i was offered bubble .
i think i 've got a bit of both nicola and bubble in me - both bonkers in different ways .
glen pierce asks : hello jane , chips with gravy or curry sauce ?
chinese or curry ?
tufty or green cross code man ?
guardian contributor janehorrocks 02 march 2016 1:46pm 1 .
curry sauce.2 .
chinese.3 .
i do n't know who tufty is !
so it has to be the green cross code man .
guardian contributor janehorrocks 02 march 2016 1:47pm so i 've just found out tufty was a squirrel .
i would never trust a squirrel to help me cross the road .
ãdhamh rogers asks : are you the kind of person who goes on rants about certain things , then gets so flustered they forgot just what they were ranting about ?
because i do that all the time : ( guardian contributor janehorrocks 02 march 2016 1:45pm i did through a period of kicking the furniture .
and then i really hurt my foot and stopped doing it .
id464998 asks : this is all a bit surreal .
joining my favourite actress in a discussion during my lunch break .
do you think you might get bored singing the same set list every night or will you decide to mash it up a bit depending on the night ?
guardian contributor janehorrocks 02 march 2016 1:44pm i 'd love to mash it up , but we have four dancers who are reliant on it being the same every night .
rat scabies , who is our drummer , on the other hand might be a little harder to control .
i wo n't sing anything by led zeppelin , because all these songs are from northern male bands in the late 70s and early 80s .
ledboots asks : is it windy where you are jane ?
it 's blowing a gale here .
guardian contributor janehorrocks 02 march 2016 1:42pm what sort of wind ?
as for whistle down the wind - in the words of shaggy : it was n't me .
deckard99 asks : would you like to come on holiday with me to a friends place in the south of france ?
i 'm a gentleman with a dirty mind .
guardian contributor janehorrocks 02 march 2016 1:40pm i do like the south of france , especially nice where i 've just filmed .
is your friend 's place in nice ?
deckard99 02 march 2016 1:44pm just near carcassonne guardian contributor janehorrocks 02 march 2016 1:55pm i 'll be at the airport in one hour .
redherrings asks : i get really turned on by the nutella scene in life is sweet .
does this make me a bad person ?
guardian contributor janehorrocks 02 march 2016 1:40pm depends how much you like nutella .
justamentalpatient asks : i think the first thing i saw jane in was came out , it rained , went back in again .
bloody hilarious !
i still use some of the lines .
guardian contributor janehorrocks 02 march 2016 1:39pm i was a virgin lesbian at the time .
someone put an egg in my hood , and i 'm not sure whether that was a come-on .
justamentalpatient asks : the ultimate question .
jaffa cakes ; biscuit or cake ?
guardian contributor janehorrocks 02 march 2016 1:38pm definitely a biscuit .
captaincheesebones asks : hi jane .
i saw you in road at stratford back in the eighties .
you slipped me a piece of paper with meet me at the beat disco tonight written on it .
i 've still got it .
guardian contributor janehorrocks 02 march 2016 1:37pm did i offer you a chip as well ?
we were handing out bags of chips from the stage .
lordpesk asks : is little princess your greatest career achievement ?
and were you like her as a child ?
guardian contributor janehorrocks 02 march 2016 1:36pm if it is my greatest achievement , i feel i 'm on the road to retirement .
as for your other question : how very dare you .

documents.title: 'mike leigh allows you to be as creative as you possibly can . and i 'm feeling that liberated again at the moment '
text: graham woods asks : hi jane .
i first saw you in life is sweet .
the interaction between nicola and her mum was so beautiful and heartbreaking .
what do you remember of working with mike leigh and the rest of that amazing cast ?
guardian contributor janehorrocks 02 march 2016 1:35pm i really enjoyed working with mike leigh , and i 'm still very proud of life is sweet .
i think what the film captures is a kindness of heart , which alison steadman and jim broadbent 's characters displayed throughout the film .
as in the words of morrissey , it takes strength to be gentle and kind .
for an actor working with mike is incredibly fulfilling , because when a director allows you to be as creative as you possibly can , it is incredibly liberating .
mike 's always guiding you , so you do n't feel you 're ever going off on a tangent .
he anchors it all the way through .
i 'm feeling that liberated again at the moment .
i think when you 're conceiving a piece with another person , you 're trusting in your own taste , and often you 're not allowed to do that .
i do n't go to the theatre very much nowadays , and if i do go , and they play a great piece of music at the beginning , i get disappointed when the music stops and the people start talking .
so i thought : why do n't you do a piece that pleases you , jane , where the music does n't stop ?
i went to david lan at the young vic with the idea , and he said yes !
ol1313 asks : what is your favourite costume you got to wear as bubble on ab fab ?
is there any chance of you coming out to australia soon ?
we 'd love to have you .

thank you and break a leg with your show : ) guardian contributor janehorrocks 02 march 2016 1:28pm i think my favourite costume in the past series is the teletubby outfit , which was designed by the brilliant rebecca hale .
and in ab fab : the movie , that 's coming out on the 1 july , the hashtag outfit .
and the kardashian arse , designed by vin and omi .
my kids are absolutely obsessed by the kardashians , so it was my two fingers to their tastes .
elephantwoman asks : before bedtime do you drink ovaltine or a cup of horrocks ?
guardian contributor janehorrocks 02 march 2016 1:26pm i used to drink ovaltine , but i 've never been a fan of a cup of horrocks .
pamn65350 asks : hi jane !
i 'm an 80s woman too !
i used to organise gigs at uni and had the honour of meeting marc almond who used to tour with his pet rabbit .
have you met any of the singers which you are covering in your new show ?
guardian contributor janehorrocks 02 march 2016 1:25pm i met new order at one point , because i did a video for one of their songs , which was called 1963 i believe .
they were very welcoming .
i 'm singing temptation in if you kiss me kiss me , which is our closing number .
i like new order because they evolved that electronic dance movement , which was very influenced by bands like kraftwerk and can .
temptation works very well for our show because it 's a celebratory song about the cyclical nature of love , which ties in very well with the themes of our show .
the whole thing is about love , and about why bands and singers choose to sing about love .
liam quane asks : hi mrs. horrocks .
can ask ; what is the best thing a director can do for you on set ?
guardian contributor janehorrocks 02 march 2016 1:20pm be supportive , and facilitate creativity .
just hearing what you 've got to offer is a start , and working with that - that 's quite rare , i think .
some can be dictatorial
cameron saunders asks : how do you get through a scene when someone is laughing all the time ?
for example many of the outtakes for ab fab .
guardian contributor janehorrocks 02 march 2016 1:18pm i find i 'm a big corpser .
and there 's one dancer in if you kiss me kiss me where i 'm going to really struggle to keep my face straight they 're not doing anything , i just look at them and want to laugh !
i find it very very difficult with jennifer saunders , we were very giggly together .
there was one scene where she had to bend down and let out a little fart , and we were cracking up - it was only joanna lumley 's stern look of disapproval that kept me together .
ms blanchedubois asks : i ca n't wait to see if you kiss me , kiss me .
young vic is one of my favourite theatres .
are you enjoying working there ?
what does yv have that other theatres do n't ?
i also wanted to ask what kind of music you listened to as a teenager or when you were in your twenties ?
have a good day !
guardian contributor janehorrocks 02 march 2016 1:16pm i 'm very much enjoying being at the young vic .
what does it have that others do n't ?
young people !
who do n't have to be overly wealthy to attend .
all the music that 's in if you kiss me kiss me , which is punk , post-punk , new wave .
it just sounded so different to everything else you 'd heard up to that point .
god save the queen in comparison to wizzard 's see my baby jive - it was just so brilliantly different and fresh .
i think i was a part-time punk - i could n't go the whole hog , which meant real commitment .
holzy asks : what happened to flossie ?
guardian contributor janehorrocks 02 march 2016 1:12pm i think she was eaten by the cat .
zwoman48 asks : yes , so where did that ultimate sally bowles ode to the disintegration of civilization come from ?
it fits our times so well .
it was horrifying .
it was magnificent .

guardian contributor janehorrocks 02 march 2016 1:12pm the rendition of cabaret was a decision : john kander who wrote the music was in rehearsal , and he was playing piano - he said you can either sing it as a celebratory song or as a purge .
he played it as a purge , and hammered the keys , and suggested i sing it as a purge .
that 's where sally bowles is at that point in the piece , it 's absolutely right - it should be a purge .
we 're still having to deal with the same sort of issues as in cabaret : separatism and racism , and the right-wing is still very prevalent today .
shalmo asks : given the choice , what gig would you want to go back to and what song would you like to see sung live ?
guardian contributor janehorrocks 02 march 2016 1:08pm i would like to go back to latitude and see kraftwerk again .
i loved the graphics - we all had to wear 3d glasses - and seeing the four guys in a row the simplicity of it , and the total magnificence of it at the same time .
i 've always wanted to do robotic dancing , and i try to do some in this production , and the director aletta collins finds it repulsive - she says it makes her feel sick .
guardian contributor janehorrocks 02 march 2016 1:09pm i would like to see die antwoord singing i fink u freeky .
i like yolandi - i just love that little girly baby voice against ninja 's rap .

25aubrey asks : hello jane , one of my favourite songs from my youth is orange juice 's fantastic rip it up and start again whenever i was met with obstacles in my life at the time , i always played this over and over again to get back on track .
what song title is appropriate to your motivational factor ?
guardian contributor janehorrocks 02 march 2016 1:06pm there 's several songs : lust for life by iggy pop , firestarter by the prodigy , me and you by nero .
lust for life though , you just instantly get a lust for life when you listen to it , and i love iggy 's voice .
nero 's just a great dance track , and prodigy - i always remember having a really good dance to that doing the film little voice , with bruno tonioni from strictly .
he was so breathless , he had to leave the dancefloor and leave me dancing .

documents.title: jane is with us now !
text: let 's get this started .
ready to tackle your questions .
beaumont-thomas

documents.title: post your questions for jane horrocks
text: for many , jane horrocks will be synonymous with bubble , the airhead fashionista in absolutely fabulous a role she 's returning to for the upcoming feature film .
for others , she 'll be always be little voice , the shy scarborough girl who found a new world in the songs of judy garland and marlene dietrich .
six years after sam mendes directed it on stage , the 1998 film adaptation garnered her bafta and golden globe nominations .

she 's now taking on a very different set of cover versions in new show if you kiss me kiss me , where she sings the beloved hits of her youth , from soft cell to new order and the smiths complete with live band and a company of dancers .

ahead of it opening at the young vic on 10 march , she 's joining us to answer your questions - on anything from life is sweet to tesco , chicken run to duetting with robbie williams - in a live webchat , from 1pm gmt onwards on wednesday 2 march .
post them in the comments below , and she 'll answer as many as possible .

bulletin.text: The Little Voice actor is covering 80s hits in her new show If You Kiss Me Kiss Me, and joined us to answer your questions. Catch up with her answers here.
